channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Winter Conditions Bring More Misery to Gaza
item.description: Rain, falling temperatures and a lack of clean water are exacerbating already dire conditions for displaced Gazans.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Children at a cooking fire between makeshift tents in the Al-Mawasi neighborhood in Rafah, southern Gaza, last week.

item.title: He Was Ready to Die, but Not to Surrender
item.description: How a Ukrainian soldier escaped from the embattled Azovstal steel complex in Mariupol and sneaked 125 miles to Ukrainian territory.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Pfc. Oleksandr Ivantsov hid for a week before beginning his journey west.

item.title: ‘God Is Under the Rubble in Gaza’: Bethlehem’s Subdued Christmas
item.description: The war in Gaza has prompted the city, traditionally seen as the birthplace of Jesus, to tone down its Christmas celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Yara Bayoumy and Samar Hazboun
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Munther Isaac lighting a candle next to an improvised crèche this month in the West Bank city of Bethlehem.

item.title: A Thriving Border Town Undercuts South Africa’s Anti-Immigrant Mood
item.description: People by the thousands risk crocodile attacks, robbery, drowning and arrest to cross the Limpopo River from Zimbabwe to South Africa, part of a booming migrant economy.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, John Eligon and Joao Silva

item.title: With Israeli Raids in the West Bank, ‘There’s No Such Thing as Sleeping at Night’
item.description: The Jenin refugee camp in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is a focal point of what Israeli officials describe as counterterrorism operations across the territory.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jenin refugee camp in December.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israel’s Military Says Battles Intensifying in Southern Gaza
item.description: Soldiers were fighting above ground in the region’s largest city, Khan Younis, Israel’s military said. The Gazan health ministry said dozens of people were killed in airstrikes in central Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians baking bread in a makeshift tent camp in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Abandoned Cemetery of Algerians Highlights Painful Episode for France
item.description: Family groups have been calling for the excavation of land believed to hold the bodies of at least 50 children — the sons and daughters of Algerians who fought for France — who died in internment camps.
item.dc:creator: Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nadia Ghouafria and Hacène Arfi walking through the remains of one of several barracks where hundreds of Algerian Harkis were kept by local authorities in Rivesaltes Camp in southern France.

item.title: Manchester United Sells 25 Percent Ownership Stake to Jim Ratcliffe
item.description: The billion-dollar deal leaves the team’s unpopular owners, the Glazer family, in control of the club, but it delegates important responsibilities to their new partner.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Manchester United playing at home last month. A loss to West Ham on Saturday dropped the club to eighth place in the Premier League.

item.title: Calls for Congo Vote to Be Annulled Mount Amid Fraud Accusations
item.description: The election in Africa’s second-largest nation, which cost over a billion dollars, is being closely followed across the world.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A polling station on Thursday in Goma, Congo.

item.title: Civilian Deaths in Custody Anger Kashmir
item.description: After a fatal ambush on Indian soldiers, several people were taken in for questioning. Three were found dead hours later, reportedly with signs of torture.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest on Saturday in Srinagar, Kashmir, after the deaths of three civilians who were detained by Indian soldiers.

item.title: Stateless People in Australia Freed From Detention, but Still Unfree
item.description: An Australian high court allowed the release of dozens of detained people who are now subject to curfews and monitored by the government with ankle bracelets.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A rally for refugee rights in Sydney, Australia, last year. Many see the country’s processing of refugees as unusually tough, often involving indefinite detention.

item.title: Putin Quietly Signals He Is Open to a Cease-Fire in Ukraine
item.description: Despite its bravado in public, the Kremlin has indicated its interest in striking a deal to halt the war — so long as it could still declare victory.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Adam Entous and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia speaking at a rally in February at Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow.

item.title: Under Argentina’s New President, Fuel Is Up 60%, and Diaper Prices Have Doubled
item.description: Javier Milei warned that things would get worse before they got better. Now Argentines are living it.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:description: Since Javier Milei took office on Dec. 10 and quickly devalued the Argentine currency, prices have risen at a dizzying pace.

item.title: Kerala Cinema Offers a Subtler View of India
item.description: “Kaathal,” about a closeted gay politician, is the latest example of what Kerala’s movie industry has become known for: nuanced films that find box office success.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Priyadarshini Ravichandran for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poster for “Kaathal” in Kochi, a city in the state of Kerala in southern India.

item.title: Mongolians Are Circus Stars All Over the World, Except at Home
item.description: Contortionists and acrobats with celestial skills train in squalid conditions as the promise of a former sumo wrestler to restore the national circus to its past glory has gone mostly unfulfilled.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jargal Lhagvasuren practiced at Old Circus, (that’s how the locals are calling the venue) which is only used by Mongolian Circus School for training now, in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia on May 18th, 2023.

item.title: Israel’s Economy Expected to Shrink 2% as War Sidelines Workers
item.description: A large segment of the Israeli work force has been called up to fight or become jobless as a result of the conflict with Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams
item.media:description: A restaurant in Sderot, Israel, that was closed in late October because of the fighting in nearby Gaza.

item.title: Hoping for Peace With Houthis, Saudis Keep Low Profile in Red Sea Conflict
item.description: Riyadh is seeking to avoid getting dragged back into a bloody clash with the Yemeni militia, which has sowed chaos by attacking shipping and firing missiles at Israel.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A portrait of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia. After spearheading a military intervention to try to rout the Houthis, he does not want to be dragged back into a conflict with them after years of war.

item.title: Christmas Comes Early in Ukraine, but Not a Moment Too Soon
item.description: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church formally changed the date for celebrating to Dec. 25, departing from the Russian tradition of celebrating on Jan. 7, according to the Julian calendar.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Santa handing out gifts to children on Friday at a festival in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Israel Says It Is Stepping Up War Against Hamas in Gaza
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said 15 Israeli soldiers had been killed since Friday, but vowed to keep fighting.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Inspecting the rubble of a destroyed building in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Sunday.

item.title: A Special Christmas Briefing
item.description: Great holiday reads and a look back at the year.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Alexandra Genova for The New York Times
item.media:description: This year, Churchtown Dairy in Claverack, N.Y., drew hundreds of carolers.

item.title: How to Create a Black Hole Out of Thin Air
item.description: Black holes were thought to arise from the collapse of dead stars. But a Webb telescope image showing the early universe hints at an alternative pathway.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: A composite image showing the quasar UHZ-1. The X-ray data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory is shown in purple; the galaxies and stars are from infrared data from the James Webb Space Telescope.

item.title: Israel Relies on Combat Dogs in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military says its dogs support elite commando units and save the lives of soldiers. But the canine unit also draws criticism.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Israel’s Golani Brigade participating in the International Military Innovation Conference last year in southern Israel.

item.title: Red Sea Shipping Halt Is Latest Risk to Global Economy
item.description: Next year could see increasing volatility as persistent military conflicts and economic uncertainty influence voting in national elections across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: India, the world’s fastest-growing economy, will hold the biggest election next year.

item.title: How Russian and Chinese Interference Could Affect the 2024 Election
item.description: The stakes for Russia in the presidential vote are large. Other adversaries also might try to deepen divisions among American voters.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters casting ballots in November. Russia appears to be paying close attention to the 2024 election, as its war in Ukraine is soon to enter a third year.

item.title: Without a Truce, U.N. Resolution May Do Little for Gaza, Aid Groups Say
item.description: The Security Council resolution, watered down to avoid a U.S. veto, directs urgent action to increase aid, but does not call for a cease-fire that would make it safe to distribute the aid.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Palestinians lining up for food in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Accuses Senior Defense Official of Embezzling $40 Million
item.description: The Ukrainian authorities said they had uncovered a scheme for the purchase of artillery shells at inflated prices, amid a wider effort to tackle wartime corruption.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers targeting Russian positions this month across the Dnipro River, in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine.

item.title: The Morning Readers’ Favorite Things of 2023
item.description: Your very specific, highly idiosyncratic best-ofs of the year.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Best of Canada in 2023
item.description: Critics at The Times highlight their favorite movies, music and more each year, and Canadians and their works feature heavily in those recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Celine Song, the South Korean-Canadian director of the film “Past Lives.”

item.title: Houthi Militia in Yemen Presents a Special Challenge for U.S.
item.description: In the past month alone, the Iranian-backed group has launched more than 100 attacks against commercial vessels in the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Newly recruited Houthi fighters during a parade this month in Amran Province, Yemen.

item.title: At Canada’s Northern College, Most of the Students are From India
item.description: The country’s public colleges and universities increasingly rely on international students, especially from India, even as tensions between the two nations have flared.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times

item.title: Brexiteers Vowed to ‘Take Back Control’ of U.K. Borders. What Happened?
item.description: Record numbers of legal immigrants came to Britain from outside the E.U. in recent years. Some on the right call that a “Brexit betrayal.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian refugee working on her résumé in a library in the village of Meopham, where she is staying with sponsors while living in England. Net migration to Britain has risen sharply since Brexit.

item.title: U.N. Resolution on Gaza Passes but Stops Short of Calling for Cease-Fire
item.description: After a week of heated negotiations, the U.N. Security Council approved a measure that called on Israel and Hamas to pause the fighting to allow for the delivery of more humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution, 13-0, on Friday that would allow for more aid to enter Gaza. The United States and Russia abstained.

item.title: Yacouba Sawadogo, African Farmer Who Held Back the Desert, Dies at 77
item.description: Against the odds, facing the encroaching Sahara, he built a forest in Burkina Faso, becoming “a national hero” and winning acclaim abroad for his innovations.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: The farmer Yacouba Sawadogo in Burkina Faso in 2021. The forest he created, with more than 60 species of trees and shrubs, has no equal in the semidesert region of the Sahel.

item.title: U.S. Increasingly Isolated Over Israel and Gaza After Leading on Ukraine
item.description: The United States finds itself in a defensive crouch and at odds with even staunch allies like France, Canada, Australia and Japan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States is becoming isolated in supporting Israel as the casualty toll of its campaign in Gaza continues to rise.

item.title: A Tokyo Taxi Driver Is Charged With Running Down a Pigeon
item.description: The arrest of the 50-year-old driver highlighted the strict law in Japan against harming the birds, even if they take over balconies or get in the way of traffic.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A pigeon at a closed shopping area near Sensoji Temple in Tokyo.

item.title: Antonio Negri, 90, Philosopher Who Wrote a Surprise Best Seller, Dies
item.description: He became famous twice: first in 1979, for his imprisonment related to the murder of a former Italian premier, and then 20 years later, for his influential book “Empire.”
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Israel Tells Gazans to Evacuate More Territory, as Offensive Grinds On
item.description: With fighting still raging in several parts of the Gaza Strip, Israeli forces are pushing deeper into central Gaza, and the war shows no sign of nearing an end.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The site of Israeli strikes in Khan Younis last week. Israeli troops are inching ahead in intense fighting in the southern city, which Israel now considers the key center of Hamas’s control.

item.title: Gadi Haggai, Listed as a Hostage, Is Now Said to Have Been Killed
item.description: Gadi Haggai, 73, was fatally shot in the Oct. 7 attack, a hostage family group says. His wife was also shot and taken captive.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Iris Weinstein Haggai/Hostage and Missing Families Forum
item.media:description: Judi Weinstein and Gadi Haggai were both shot while taken hostage on Oct. 7 during an attack on Kibbutz Nir Oz.

item.title: Strike in Somalia Said to Kill Mastermind of Attacks on Americans and Kenyans
item.description: Maalim Ayman, a senior leader of the extremist group al-Shabab, was believed responsible for attacks in Kenya on a university town that killed 148 people, and on a U.S. military base that killed three Americans.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Diana Zeyneb Alhindawi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Somali commando unit during training by U.S. forces in Baledogle, Somalia, in February.

item.title: It’s OK to Call It Soccer
item.description: The football-vs.-soccer debate is not about language at all.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Mood when someone writes in to say, “It’s football, not soccer.”

item.title: U.S.-Led Talks Seek to Ease Tension on Israel-Lebanon Border
item.description: The first goal of the secret negotiations is to stop skirmishes between Israel and Hezbollah from escalating into an all-out war, but longer-term solutions are also on the table, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous, Ronen Bergman, Maria Abi-Habib and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Smoke rising on the Lebanese side of the border after an Israeli airstrike last month. Israel’s war with Hamas in Gaza has led to fears of a conflict with Lebanon.

item.title: Russia Makes Small Battlefield Gains, Increasing Pressure on Ukraine
item.description: Although there is no clear breakthrough in sight, the progress is prompting Ukraine to consider a possible large-scale recruitment push.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing a Cold War-era Soviet gun toward Russian positions in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine last month.

item.title: A Lucrative Tax Credit for Making Clean Fuel Won’t Be So Easy to Get
item.description: Experts had warned that efforts to build a vast new hydrogen industry could inadvertently worsen global warming. New rules aim to avoid that.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden visited the Cummins Power Generation Facility in Fridley, Minn., the site of an electrolyzer manufacturing operation, in April.

item.title: When the season calls for merry murder mysteries
item.description: Agatha Christie spirits me away to fancy houses and glamorous island retreats.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Agatha Christie at work in her home, Greenway House, in southwestern England, in 1946.

item.title: How Cecilia Blomdahl in Svalbard Embraces Dark Days in the Arctic
item.description: Svalbard, an island in the Arctic, has about one of everything, including a social media influencer with millions of followers.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Cecilia Blomdahl and her dog, Grim, live on the archipelago of Svalbard, near the North Pole.

item.title: Japan Relaxes Weapons Export Policy To Sell Patriot Missiles To U.S.
item.description: The policy change could shore up American supplies of the weapon, allowing Washington to send more to Ukraine to help in its war against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Patriot missiles in Okinawa Prefecture, Japan. The country has changed regulations on the export of weapons that have been in place for most of the post-World War II era.

item.title: Mass Shooting in Prague Brings Grief and a Focus on Guns
item.description: After a student killed 14 people at a premier university, questions swirled. Did the Czech Republic’s permissive attitude toward gun ownership play a role?
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Police officers outside a Charles University building in Prague on Friday.

item.title: U.S. to Clamp Down on Financial Firms That Help Russia Buy Military Supplies
item.description: President Biden signed an executive order granting the Treasury Department broader powers to curb the flow of weapons components.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators examined a crater caused by a Russian missile in Kyiv this month.

item.title: Hamas Hostages and Families of Captives Sue the Red Cross in Israeli Court
item.description: The lawsuit comes as the Red Cross has come under mounting political pressure from Israelis and their leaders.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: Several posters showing the faces of Israeli hostages held in Gaza are pasted on a house in Kibbutz Be’eri, Israel, which Hamas militants was attacked on Oct. 7.

item.title: For Archbishop of Canterbury, Heading Anglican Church Is ‘High-Wire Act’
item.description: Serving as the spiritual leader of 85 million Anglicans in an increasingly secular world is just one of the challenges for Justin Welby. He also had a king to crown and immigration policy to condemn.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, archbishop of Canterbury, in the chapel at Lambeth Palace, his residence in London, in December.

item.title: Ukrainians Urge Spending Shift as War Drags On
item.description: Protesters are lobbying city councils to freeze urban renewal projects and buy military equipment instead, part of a wider call to put Ukraine on a war footing.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Hundreds of Ukrainians gathered last week to demand that the Kyiv City Council end road repairs and freeze construction of a subway depot, and direct the money to the war against Russia.

item.title: 96% of Saudis Believe Arab Countries Should Cut Ties with Israel, Poll Finds
item.description: The poll’s results reveal hurdles to the Biden administration’s push for Saudi Arabia to establish diplomatic relations with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: The Rahmah Mosque area in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. A poll found that 40 percent of Saudis expressed positive attitudes toward Hamas, compared with 10 percent in a poll several months before the Gaza war began.

item.title: North Korea’s New Reactor Increases Ability to Produce Plutonium
item.description: ​A light-water reactor could provide more weapons-grade plutonium, abetting the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un’s vow to expand his nuclear arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image provided by North Korean state media this week showed Kim Jong Un, left, and his daughter watching the test launch of a Hwasong-18 intercontinental ballistic missile at an undisclosed location in North Korea.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A deadly shooting spree in the Czech Republic.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A vigil at Charles University in Prague on Thursday.

item.title: A Times Investigation Tracked Israel’s Use of One of Its Most Destructive Bombs in South Gaza
item.description: A Times visual investigation reveals that one of Israel’s largest munitions was regularly being dropped in areas designated safe for i
item.dc:creator: Robin Stein, Haley Willis, Ishaan Jhaveri, Danielle Miller, Aaron Byrd and Natalie Reneau
item.media:credit: The New York Times, Source: Planet Labs

item.title: Widow of Jamal Khashoggi Is Granted Political Asylum in the U.S.
item.description: The successful petition is one of the few recent reminders of the fallout from the killing of Mr. Khashoggi, a Washington Post columnist.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:description: A candlelight vigil for Jamal Khashoggi in front of the Saudi Embassy in Washington in 2019. “I can feel more safe now that I’m not afraid to be handed over to any dictator in the Middle East,” his widow said.

item.title: U.S. Ready to Back U.N. Resolution to Allow More Aid Into Gaza
item.description: The timing for a vote on the Security Council resolution was unclear. Diplomats were focused on who would oversee the inspection of aid entering the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: U.N. headquarters in New York. Diplomats were working on an aid deal for Gaza.

item.title: Friday Briefing: U.N. Prepares to Vote on Gaza Aid
item.description: Plus, how wealthy was the family in “Home Alone”?
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Palestinians lining up for a meal in the city of Rafah amid food shortages on Thursday in southern Gaza.

item.title: Hamas Frees Teenage Hostage, but Her Father Is Still in Gaza
item.description: Sahar Kalderon, 16, spent 52 days as a hostage. She says she cannot enjoy her freedom until her father, Ofer, is free.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: David Blumenfeld for The New York Times

item.title: ‘There Was No Sense of Time’: Israeli Teen Recounts Captivity in Gaza
item.description: Sahar Kalderon, 16, was abducted from Kibbutz Nir Oz on Oct. 7. Her father and 12-year-old brother were also kidnapped. The siblings were released on Nov. 27 as part of a cease-fire deal. Their father remains in captivity.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr, Carmit Hoomash, Caroline Kim and David Blumenfeld
item.media:credit: David Blumenfeld for The New York Times

item.title: Gaza Death Toll Nears 20,000 During Israel-Hamas War
item.description: The death toll reported in Gaza has surpassed 20,000, according to officials in the territory, the heaviest loss on the Arab side in any war with Israel since the 1982 Lebanon invasion.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians bidding farewell to relatives killed in the war at Nasser hospital in Khan Younis this month.
